headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of May 6-7, 2017.

headline: Texas Officer to Be Charged With Murder in Shooting of Black 15-Year-Old
summary: A Texas police officer who shot and killed a black 15-year-old boy in a Dallas suburb will face murder charges, law enforcement officials said Friday.

headline: Trump’s Army Secretary Nominee Mark Green Withdraws
summary: President Donald Trump’s nominee for secretary of the Army has pulled his name from consideration for the post after a siege by lawmakers and advocates who objected to stands he previously had taken on social issues.

headline: Commodities Rattled by Softening Demand From China
summary: A global commodities slump deepened Friday before prices stabilized later in the day, but iron-ore prices continued to plummet.

headline: FDA Approves First ALS Drug in Over Two Decades
summary: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first drug in more than two decades for the treatment of ALS, the paralyzing and fatal malady often called Lou Gehrig’s disease.

headline: Buffett’s Berkshire Reports Drop in Net Earnings
summary: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway said its first-quarter net earnings fell 27%, hurt by weaker investment gains.

headline: The Labor Market Tightens
summary: Wages are rising but there’s still a growing worker shortage.

headline: A Korean Election Nail-Biter
summary: A Trump blunder has helped the soft-on-North-Korea candidate.

headline: Big Labor Looks at California’s Marijuana Market and Sees Green
summary: ‘This is a growing industry,’ says a Teamsters lobbyist, ‘and we’d like it to grow unionized.’

headline: Fraternity and 18 Members Charged in Penn State Student’s Death
summary: A Penn State fraternity pledge died after stumbling and falling several times with toxic levels of alcohol in his body and suffered for hours with severe injuries while his friends failed to summon help, authorities said Friday in announcing criminal charges against the fraternity and 18 of its members.

headline: Purdue Defends Plan to Acquire Kaplan in Wake of Faculty Vote
summary: Purdue University on Friday defended its plan to acquire Kaplan University, a day after the public university’s faculty gave a thumbs down to the deal to take over the for-profit, mostly online school.

headline: Fed’s Williams Sees Future Balance Sheet Size Starting at $2 Trillion
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams said he could see the U.S. central bank’s balance sheet settling somewhere above $2 trillion, concurring with several estimates that have put the figure at least that high in the absence of a specific prediction from the Fed.

headline: Decades in an Asylum Wasn’t the Worst Fate
summary: My mentally ill great-uncle spent 72 years in custody. Today he’d be isolated in a prison cell—or maybe homeless and dangerous.

headline: Let’s Get Metaphysical About Trump and the ‘Post-Truth Era’
summary: The nature of truth is a difficult philosophical problem, but the president hasn’t made it any harder.

headline: List of National Monuments Under Review Is Unveiled
summary: The Interior Department released a list of about two dozen national monuments and marine preserves to be reviewed for possible downsizing or elimination, including two of the more contentious in recent years: Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante, both in Utah.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Gold Investing?
summary: Here’s a Wall Street Journal quiz to test your knowledge about gold.

headline: Stormy Mood, Tempestuous Brushstrokes
summary: Titian portrait of ‘Doge Andrea Gritti’ is in almost the same condition as the day it left the artist’s studio.

headline: Podcast: Why Getting a Low-Pay Job Out of College is Good
summary: Some students will start out in a first job that pays below the national average. Here are some of the hidden blessings.

headline: ‘Los Elementos’ Review: Far From a Force of Nature
summary: New York City Opera stumbles with a difficult work: a plotless 18th-century allegory in which the four Elements debate their respective powers.

headline: How to Use ‘529’ College-Savings Plans
summary: Watching Your Wealth podcast: Brian Boswell, vice president at Savingforcollege.com, shares tips on how to use “529” college-savings plans.

headline: Trustee Sues Doctors at Humble Surgical Hospital Over Alleged Billing Scam
summary: The Texas accountant who is operating the bankrupt Humble Surgical Hospital filed a lawsuit against 104 doctors who he says participated in an illegal billing scam.

headline: National Monuments That Could Soon Be on the Chopping Block
summary: President Trump said Wednesday he wanted to stop the “massive federal land grab” of designating national monuments in an executive order signing ceremony.

headline: Judge Sets Trial Date in ‘El Chapo’ Case for April 2018
summary: Attorneys for Joaquín ‘El Chapo’ Guzman, who appeared in court for the first time in three months, told a judge that the strict conditions of his solitary confinement were beginning to make communicating with their client untenable.

headline: Dollar Pares Gains After Jobs Report
summary: The dollar pared gains Friday after a report showed U.S. hiring rebounded in April but the pace of wage growth slowed.

headline: April Jobs Report Hints at Growth in Logistics Industry
summary: Businesses tied to e-commerce fulfillment resumed hiring at a rapid clip in April, bolstering payrolls to meet changes in the consumer economy.

headline: The Post-ObamaCare Fiesta
summary: Who was really celebrating on Thursday in Washington?

headline: Wireless Weakness Leads to a Verizon Warning on Credit Rating
summary: Verizon Communications Inc. warned it won’t be able to raise its credit rating as quickly as promised after a major debt ratings firm gave the company less room for error in a sagging wireless industry.

headline: Puerto Rico Bond Default Called Over Fiscal Plan’s Debt Cuts
summary: Bank of New York Mellon, the trustee for $17 billion in sales-tax bonds known as Cofinas, notified Puerto Rico in a Thursday letter that it believes events of default have occurred.

headline: Yellen Says Family-Friendly Work Policies Can Boost Economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen said family-friendly policies that increase women’s participation in the workforce could boost economic growth and help the U.S. overcome longer-term challenges.

headline: Trump Campaign Associates Questioned Over Russia Ties
summary: A Senate committee has asked at least four former associates of the Trump campaign for information about their activities before and after the election, a sign that the committee’s probe into alleged Russian campaign interference is heating up.

headline: CMO Today: Media Investors Worry About Soft Ad-Market, Cord-Cutting
summary: Here's your morning roundup of the biggest marketing, advertising and media industry news and happenings.

headline: Treasurys Steady After Jobs Report
summary: U.S. government bonds steadied Friday after a two-day selloff, as the latest jobs data reaffirmed expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month even as it failed to produce the surge in economic optimism that some had anticipated.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 5
summary: In photos selected Friday by Wall Street Journal editors, Sri Lankan Buddhists prepare to celebrate Vesak Day, children become U.S. citizens at a ceremony, heavy rains flood Quebec, and more.

headline: What Selloff? Wall Street Still Bullish on Oil After Plunge
summary: Wall Street analysts are keeping their bullish forecasts for oil prices, despite a 13% plunge in crude over the past three weeks.

headline: U.K. Local Election Results Bode Well for May in National Vote
summary: The U.K.’s governing Conservative Party made significant gains in local elections, which could herald a big win for Prime Minister Theresa May in a nationwide vote next month.

headline: U.S. Consumer Credit Increased by $16.43 Billion in March
summary: Outstanding consumer credit, a measure of non-real-estate debt, rose by $16.43 billion in March from the prior month, climbing at a 5.2% seasonally adjusted annual rate, the Federal Reserve said.

headline: We Must Be Smarter in Buying Needed Arms
summary: Former Navy Secretary John Lehman proposes a two-pronged strategy to reduce defense procurement costs: Cost-plus contracting gives a perverse incentive to stay inefficient.

headline: Saving vs. Spending: What Is Wealth For?
summary: Regarding “When Good Money Habits Turn Against You”: In my retirement, I am deriving pleasure from assuming the strategy “I am through saving, now I am spending.”

headline: VW Diesel Cars Caught in Emissions Scandal Begin Flying Off Lots
summary: Volkswagen’s TDI diesel cars are back on sale in the U.S. after being yanked from the market 18 months ago over emissions issues, sparking a race among buyers for the extremely limited supply.

headline: The Bad Side Effects of Personalized Medicine
summary: Regarding Peter Huber and Paul Howard’s “Personalized Medicine Is Here”: Big data and genetic analysis present both opportunity and danger.

headline: Former Socialiste Macron Is Not a Politician of the Center
summary: Regarding Joseph Sternberg’s “Emmanuel Macron as the ‘Hope of France’”: as a longtime member of the French Parti Socialiste, Macron is just a less-shaggy version of socialist Bernie Sanders, not a centrist like John Kennedy.

headline: Trump Signs $1.1 Trillion Spending Bill, Avoiding Government Shutdown
summary: President Donald Trump on Friday signed a $1.1 trillion bill to fund the government through Sept. 30, avoiding a partial government shutdown this weekend while conceding on several of his key priorities.

headline: We Need More Saving, Not Less: Hands Off the 401(k)s
summary: Yes, Congress should keep the tax advantage of contributions to individual-retirement accounts, as detailed in Jason Zweig’s “The Intelligent Investor: Grab the Pitchforks, Your 401(k) May Need to Ward Off Congress”

headline: Metals: Gold Prices Fall to One-Month Low
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-month low on Friday after U.S. jobs data showed stronger-than-expected employment in April.

headline: Five Best: Sarah Ruden
summary: The author, most recently, of “The Face of Water: A Translator on Beauty and Meaning in the Bible” on lost worlds.

headline: A Twins Study Shows ADHD Isn’t Just Genetic
summary: Research of twins suggests that Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder isn’t just genetic.

headline: The Best New Children’s Books
summary: Meghan Cox Gurdon on Gaia Cornwall’s “Jabari Jumps” and other picture books.

headline: How Your Brain Digests Your Dinner
summary: The perception and appreciation of flavor may be a uniquely human gift. Steven Poole reviews “Flavor: The Science of Our Most Neglected Sense” by Bob Holmes.

headline: Economic Change Is Slow to Come to South Los Angeles
summary: Twenty-five years ago this week, the Rodney King riots tore apart South Los Angeles for six days. Community leaders and entrepreneurs are still trying to revive the local economy. There are signs of success, but poverty persists.

headline: NYPD Searches for Suspect in Assault of German Tourist
summary: Police searched for a violent robber on Friday who allegedly beat and sexually assaulted a German tourist outside of her Airbnb rental in upper Manhattan, according to Robert Boyce, chief of detectives.

headline: Gentriﬁcation and Its Discontents
summary: Cities attract the rich with amenities and the poor with services. But they are failing the middle class. Edward Glaeser reviews “The New Urban Crisis” by Richard Florida.

headline: Murderous Mothers and Children
summary: Sam Sacks reviews “House of Names” by Colm Tóibín and “Inheritance From Mother” by Minae Mizumura.

headline: Sam Shepard’s True West
summary: The playwright’s drifters and dreamers do battle with destiny on a Shakespearean level. Ethan Mordden reviews “Sam Shepard” by John J. Winters.

headline: Here Be Dragons
summary: Tom Shippey on two new fantasies: “Red Sister” by Mark Lawrence and “The Dragon’s Legacy” by Deborah A. Wolf.

headline: The Nuclear Winter White House
summary: Inside the government’s elaborate plans to survive catastrophic attack. Howard Schneider reviews “Raven Rock” by Garrett M. Graff.

headline: Do White House Meetings Boost a Firm’s Market Value?
summary: Two finance professors say that executives’ meetings with top administration officials were associated with higher short-term stock returns.

headline: Best-Selling Books Week Ended April 30
summary: Best-Selling Books | Week Ended April 30, with data from NPD BookScan

headline: U.S. Oil-Rig Count Rises by 6
summary: The number of rigs drilling for oil in the U.S. rose six to 703 in the past week. Oil-rig count typically is viewed as a proxy for activity in the sector.

headline: Quantitative Investing: A Crisis Waiting to Happen
summary: Richard Bookstaber says several factors combine to make quantitative models, and the funds and risk-management techniques based on them, fatally flawed.

headline: Businesses Compete for Workers, Raise Pay as Labor Market Tightens
summary: With unemployment down to 4.4%, businesses across an array of industries are struggling to find workers, and in some cases have started to raise wages at a faster clip.

headline: The Birth of Criminal Profiling
summary: Finding a “Mad Bomber” loose in New York City led to a new way to solve crime. Peter Duffy reviews “Incendiary” by Michael Cannell.

headline: In the Netherlands, Mondrian Across the Decades
summary: The Gemeentemuseum in The Hague will feature an exhibition of Piet Mondrian’s work, from student art to his last masterpiece in New York.

headline: For Arab Gulf States, Israel Is Emerging as an Ally
summary: Sunni monarchies, led by Saudi Arabia, increasingly see the Jewish state as a partner in a common struggle against Shiite Iran.

headline: How to Send a Fax When You Don’t Have a Fax Machine
summary: A decades-old technology refuses to die—at least at many realty offices, banks, law firms and medical centers.

headline: Djokovic Ditches Coaches Amid Slump
summary: The former world No. 1 said he wouldn’t rush to find a replacement after the move he called “shock therapy” for his struggling game

headline: The Google Docs Worm: How to Protect Against Email Spoofing
summary: The incident showed how a common, relatively benign scam can quickly turn into a threat to a company’s brand.

headline: Morgan Stanley Considers Not Paying Brokers for Clients’ Vanguard Holdings
summary: Morgan Stanley is considering compensation changes for its financial advisers that could discourage them from keeping clients in mutual funds of Vanguard Group, which doesn’t pay other firms to sell its funds.

headline: Texas’s Immigration Bill Allows for Jailing of Police Who Disobey
summary: Texas lawmakers voted to send Gov. Greg Abbott a bill to bar municipalities and police departments from adopting sanctuary policies for illegal immigrants and fine those who disobey.

headline: Sam Zell Looks Back
summary: The notoriously blunt real-estate magnate on being contrarian, not taking yourself too seriously and other business lessons he’s learned.

headline: LendingClub: Where’s the Growth?
summary: The online lender isn’t immune to broader problems in consumer credit.

headline: In France, Voters Can Choose Le Pen, Macron—Or No One
summary: Activists are campaigning for a change to election law that would allow blank ballots to be included in official tallies, a move they say would allow disaffected voters to force fresh elections.

headline: Navy SEAL Killed Fighting Militants in Somalia
summary: A U.S. Navy SEAL was killed while fighting an al Qaeda-affiliated militant group in Somalia. Defense officials said it appeared to be the first U.S. combat death in Somalia since 1993.

headline: The Art of Portrait Medals
summary: ‘The Pursuit of Immortality,’ at New York’s Frick Collection, showcases intricately made medals starting from the Renaissance.

headline: Goldman’s Blankfein Warns on Brexit Risks to London
summary: London’s expansion as a financial center could “stall” and banks may need to consider moving staff out of the city because of Brexit, the Goldman Sachs CEO warned.

headline: Tight Jobs Market Equals Higher Pay, Lower Profits
summary: The job market’s move from tightening to tight could mark a change for investors used to being the winners in the long-running battle between capital and labor.

headline: Jury Awards $110 Million to Plaintiff in J&J Baby Powder Case
summary: Johnson & Johnson was hit with a $110 million jury decision in favor of a woman who said talc in the company’s baby powder gave her ovarian cancer, the latest—and largest—verdict yet in the litigation saga.

headline: Puerto Rico to Close 184 Public Schools
summary: Puerto Rico is closing 184 public schools in a move expected to save millions of dollars amid a deep economic crisis that has sparked an exodus to the U.S. mainland in the past decade.

headline: Pearson Rises on Review of U.S. Courseware Unit, Cost Cuts
summary: Pearson shares jumped after the world’s largest education company said it may sell its U.S. school courseware publishing business and will cut more jobs.

headline: Where to Find Great Volunteer Vacations
summary: Also: Answers to questions about 401(k)s, IRAs and Social Security

headline: North Korea Accuses CIA of Assassination Plot
summary: North Korea accused the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency of trying to assassinate its leader Kim Jong Un, giving details of an alleged terrorist plot, a fresh reflection of the heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang.

headline: The Scene at Louis Vuitton’s ‘Masters’ Party
summary: A discreetly attired ready-to-shop crowd feted Louis Vuitton’s new collaboration with Jeff Koons and its dedicated pop-up shop. Plus, Cartier’s revives an elegant evening timepiece.

headline: China Insurance Regulator Bars Anbang Life From Selling Two Products
summary: China’s insurance regulator clipped the wings of highflying Anbang Insurance Group, prohibiting the firm’s life insurance subsidiary from selling two investment products and seeking approval to sell new ones for three months

headline: Analysis: Jobs Report Keeps Fed on Track for Likely June Rate Increase
summary: The strong April jobs report means the Federal Reserve is even more likely to raise short-term interest rates at its next meeting, June 13-14, and keep lifting them gradually this year to keep the economy from overheating.

headline: Masterpiece Theater
summary: The scene at Louis Vuitton’s ‘Masters’ party

headline: The Sinister History of ‘Going Left’
summary: From Greek omens to the last week’s disastrous Fyre Festival, Ben Zimmer on the sinister history of the phrase ‘going left.’

headline: More Nasties of History Get a Novel Makeover
summary: Now that a novelist has humanized the depraved emperor Nero, Joe Queenan imagines renovations are in store for more bad guys. A traumatized Jack the Ripper, anyone?

headline: Kentucky Derby Is a Favorite for a ‘Super’-Size Wager
summary: The Kentucky Derby’s popularity and large field of horses offer a chance to hit on a lucrative version of the superfecta—correctly predicting in order the first four horses to cross the finish line.

headline: Fannie Mae to Send $2.8 Billion Dividend to Treasury
summary: Fannie Mae said it would send a $2.8 billion dividend payment to the U.S. Treasury in June as the company’s delinquency rate continued to fall amid increasing home prices.

headline: Canada Job Growth Slows in April; Jobless Rate Falls
summary: Canada’s employment growth decelerated in April while the jobless rate fell to its lowest level in nearly nine years as fewer people, in particular younger people, looked for work.

headline: Robert Ratliff Welded Castoff Farm-Machinery Brands Into a Global Business
summary: When he was in his late 50s, Robert Ratliff’s career prospects looked dim. He helped found AGCO, one of the world’s biggest makers of farm equipment, and oversaw 21 acquisitions.

headline: Mother’s Diagnosis Changed the Script for Sitcom Writer Trish Vradenburg
summary: Sitcom writer and novelist Trish Vradenburg created an organization to support Alzheimer’s research after watching her mother succumb to the disease.

headline: Lawyer ‘Racehorse’ Haynes Used Theatric Flair to Defend His Clients
summary: As a criminal-defense lawyer, Richard “Racehorse” Haynes always liked a challenge. In the 1970s and 1980s, at his career’s peak, Mr. Haynes was one of the most famous lawyers in the U.S.

headline: New Mountain Capital Reaches Deal for VWR
summary: New Mountain Capital’s Avantor reached an agreement to buy laboratory-supply distributor VWR in a roughly $4.38 billion deal to diversify and capture a larger global presence.

headline: Elliott Says Akzo Nobel’s Independence Will Put More Jobs at Risk
summary: Activist investor Elliott Management accelerated its campaign to push Dutch paints giant Akzo Nobel to engage in sale talks with U.S. rival PPG Industries, citing research it commissioned that Akzo’s go-it-alone plans would put the company’s employees at risk.

headline: Algeria’s Ruling Parties Win Majority of Seats in New Parliament
summary: The ruling National Liberation Front and its coalition ally have won a majority of seats in Algerian parliamentary elections marked by a low turnout.

headline: Anthem to Petition Supreme Court to Review Rulings Blocking Cigna Deal
summary: Anthem said it would petition the Supreme Court to review the antitrust rulings blocking its acquisition of Cigna, a long-shot bid to revive a $48 billion deal amid litigation between the two companies.

headline: Oil-Plunge Explanation Isn’t That Scary
summary: After six exuberant months, oil and commodities markets have awakened to the realization that neither China’s big stimulus nor Trump’s election is a game changer. But that doesn’t signal the collapse of global growth.

headline: Indonesia Hunts for Inmates After Major Jailbreak
summary: Scores of prisoners fled an overcrowded jail on Sumatra island after overwhelming guards as they were let out of their cells to take part in prayers.

headline: After Months of Steady Growth, Economists See China Slowing
summary: China’s economy, after chugging along in recent months, is likely losing some steam, with some economists expecting indicators for April to show weaker industrial production, softer overall credit and cooler export growth.

headline: India Supreme Court Upholds Death Penalty in Infamous Gang Rape
summary: India’s highest court upheld the death sentence for four men convicted of the 2012 rape and murder of a college student that exposed the country to searing global scrutiny and drove changes in the law meant to better protect women.

headline: How Pro Golf Became a Bromance
summary: Today’s top golfers appear friendlier than ever, but not everyone thinks chumminess is the best look.

headline: An Artist Finds Inspiration For His Art in Science
summary: His paintings are an attempt to convey the implications of research in easily accessible ways

headline: Screws Tighten on Risky Chinese Insurance
summary: In China, lucrative bets are usually followed by a regulatory clampdown. So it was only a matter of time before China’s acquisitive and unlisted life insurers started feeling the pain.

headline: Justice Department Investigating Baxter Over Saline Shortage
summary: The Department of Justice is probing Baxter International Inc. as part of an investigation into whether large producers of saline solutions and other injectable medicines colluded to create supply shortages so they could benefit from higher prices

headline: The 10-Point: Gerard Baker on the GOP Health-Care Bill, China’s Financial Clampdown, Uber’s ‘Greyball’ Probe and More
summary: A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

headline: How GM Might Unlock a Tesla-Like Valuation
summary: An idea to separate GM’s future-technology projects from its core production business would help meet investor demand for car-tech plays

headline: Trump to Meet EU Officials in Brussels
summary: The top leaders of the European Union will meet with President Donald Trump during his visit to Brussels this month, officials from the bloc announced.

headline: China Seeks Foothold in Aviation With Flight of Its First Big Passenger Jet
summary: China is expected to pass a technology milestone on Friday with the maiden flight of its first big commercial airliner, launching what Beijing hopes will become a rival to Boeing and Airbus.

headline: U.S. Jet Fighters Flex Muscle Amid Russia Tensions
summary: The Pentagon has deployed its newest combat plane, the stealthy F-35A fighter, to Europe for a first overseas training mission in a show of allied strength intended in part to deter Russia.

headline: More Companies Willing to Take on the CFPB
summary: Companies targeted by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau are more frequently choosing to fight enforcement actions rather than settle, as Republican control of the White House has put the agency’s future in doubt.

headline: Ocwen Swiftly Went on Counterattack Against the CFPB
summary: Five days after it was accused of illegally practices, Ocwen Financial Corp. turned to audacious action: It asked a court to dismiss the lawsuit, saying the watchdog agency making the allegations is unconstitutional.

headline: Tax Moves to Make Now, Ahead of Potential Overhaul
summary: To make the most of President Donald Trump’s tax proposals, experts say individuals should consider deferring income, accelerating donations to maximize benefits if brackets or deductions are changed.

headline: Europe Leads as Industrial 3-D Printing Takes Shape
summary: For General Electric and its rivals expanding their manufacturing operations using 3-D printing, Europe is emerging as a dominant source of the latest technologies.

headline: VW Brand CEO Aims to Boost Profit Through Productivity Gains, Cost-Control
summary: Volkswagen’s struggling namesake brand said it expects to wrap up the technical fixes of most tainted diesel vehicles by the end of the year and boost productivity and profits in its main automotive operations.

headline: European Airlines Set for Lift From Rising Ticket Prices
summary: European airlines are flying into smoother air with ticket prices, bolstered by improving corporate bookings and steadily growing economies, showing signs of recovery after years of sharp falls.

headline: China Commodities Slump Weighs on Stocks
summary: Commodities took center stage in Asia, with a slump in Chinese metals prices and weakness in crude oil sending equity markets across the region lower.

headline: Senate Tackles Rewrite on GOP Health-Care Bill
summary: Republican senators aim to begin a formal full rewrite of the House GOP health-care bill, driven in part by a sense that the House version made insurance less expensive for young people but costlier for older Americans—an influential, mostly GOP voting bloc.

headline: U.S. Dismisses Russia’s Ban on Aircraft Over Syrian Safe Zones
summary: A Russian envoy said U.S. aircraft are barred from flying over the “de-escalation zones” that Russia, Iran and Turkey recently agreed to establish in Syria, but U.S. officials dismissed the idea.

headline: S&P 500, Nasdaq End Week at Records
summary: Solid corporate earnings and a slightly stronger-than-expected April jobs report lifted the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite to fresh records.

headline: Brazil Testimony Points to Pemex Bribe
summary: A former top official of Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht SA testified that he was asked in 2014 to bribe the then-head of Mexican state oil firm Petróleos Mexicanos, according to a document filed withas part of a broader corruption probe.

headline: When the CEO Met the CEO President
summary: United Technologies head Gregory Hayes on how Trump kept the Carrier plant open—and the high-paid factory jobs he’s having trouble filling.

headline: Blank Check Debuts on Big Board After NYSE Eases Rules
summary: Blank-check listings—by companies with no assets that are raising cash for acquisitions—have become an increasingly important part of the initial public offering market, and NYSE is getting in on the action.

headline: Oil Rebounds
summary: Crude futures bounced back from five-month lows Friday, following a week of steep losses globally as investors continue to worry about brimming crude inventories.

headline: Frederick Douglass, Feminist
summary: The orator saw freedom for slaves and power for women as two fronts in the same war. Fergus M. Bordewich reviews “Women in the World of Frederick Douglass” by Leigh Fought.

headline: Chaos in Lincoln’s High Command
summary: The president struggled to find a leader who could match Robert E. Lee. Russell S. Bonds reviews “Lincoln’s Lieutenants” by Stephen W. Sears.

headline: The Pied Piper of MI5
summary: Before World War II, Maxwell Knight’s spies infiltrated both far-left and far-right groups. Richard Davenport-Hines reviews “Agent M” by Henry Hemming.

headline: What to Consider Before Retiring in a College Town
summary: Retirement expert Glenn Ruffenach also answers questions on IRAs and health care when retiring abroad.

headline: Venezuela Is Starving
summary: Once Latin America’s richest country, Venezuela can no longer feed its people, hobbled by the nationalization of farms as well as price and currency controls. The resulting hunger and malnutrition are an unfolding tragedy.

headline: This Tiny Arctic Town Loves Visitors, Unless They’re Automotive Spies
summary: In the Northern Swedish village of Arjeplog, where auto makers test secret prototypes on iced-over lakes, car photographers are considered a public nuisance.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Cuts Stake in IBM
summary: The company sold about a third of its shares in International Business Machines Corp. this year at a price above $180 each, Mr. Buffett said.

headline: 14 Players to Watch in Senate Health-Care Overhaul
summary: A look at the mostly Republican cast of characters who will hammer out legislation to replace the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Companies Rack Up Profits, but Aren’t Ready to Spend Them
summary: The largest U.S. companies are booking their strongest quarterly profits in five years, as firms reap the benefits of years of belt tightening and finally see a pickup in demand. But part of the improvement has come from keeping a lid on spending, and many CEOs remain reluctant to change that.

headline: How to Raise an American Adult
summary: Many young Americans today are locked in perpetual adolescence. Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse on how he and his wife are encouraging their own children to become fully formed, independent grown-ups.

headline: Virtu CEO Aims to Be the Good Guy of High-Speed Trading
summary: High-frequency trading firms are often cast as villains. Virtu Financial Chief Executive Douglas Cifu is determined to be seen as one of the good guys.

headline: China Sews Up Record $43 Billion Foreign Takeover but Work Remains
summary: ChemChina said shareholders of Swiss agribusiness giant Syngenta accepted its takeover offer valued at about $43 billion, paving the way for the completion of China’s largest foreign acquisition to date.

headline: Assessing the Impact of the House GOP Health Bill
summary: If the Senate approves the House GOP health-care bill as is, nearly every participant in the nation’s health system would have to adjust.

headline: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ
summary: Delivering up-to-the minute news, analysis, interviews and explanatory journalism on logistics, supply-chain management, e-commerce and more

headline: Liquor Makers Step Up Efforts to Win Over Hispanic Drinkers
summary: The world’s biggest liquor makers look to woo a growing group of legal drinkers: Hispanics.

headline: China’s Push to Stabilize Financial System Leaves Markets in Disarray
summary: A wave of regulations aimed at cutting risk in China’s financial system are rippling through the country’s markets and sending banks and companies scrambling for funds.

headline: GOP Approves Bill to Replace Most of Affordable Care Act
summary: House Republicans approved legislation Thursday to replace most of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: U.S. Economy Poised for Spring Rebound as Jobless Rate Falls
summary: Hiring increased in April, and the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level in a decade, signs the U.S. economy is rebounding after a lackluster winter.
